title: The ternary operator
postscript: Although some coders love using the ternary operator, it's best to avoid it because it doesn't make your code very clear.
question: This code will print "Success" – true or false?
hint: The part after the question mark is executed if the condition is true, the part after the colon if it's false, and Swift won't let you compare different types of data.

correct.reason: Because numberOfCats is greater than 18, this will print "Success".
Because strongMagnets is true, this will print "Success".
Because phone is not "Android" this will print "Success".
Because dexterity is equal to 18, this will print "Success".

correct.answer:
let isComplete: Bool = false
print(isComplete == true ? "Failure" : "Success")
correct.reason: Because isComplete is false, this will print "Success".
Because sides is less than 6, this will print "Success".

wrong.reason: isRecyclable is false, so this will print "Failure".

wrong.answer:
let highScore = 90
let actualScore = 89
print(actualScore > highScore ? "Success" : "Failure")
wrong.reason: actualScore is less than highScore so this will print "Failure".
storageSpace is less than 1000, so this will print "Failure".
This attempts to compare a string and an integer, which is invalid.
averagePages is 10.01, and this condition checks for exactly 10, so this will print "Failure".
